evidence.mechanism: Tree provides O(log k) latency; LL128 achieves ~95% bandwidth with ~2us/hop. Synergistic for medium messages (98KB-12MB) where both latency and bandwidth matter. LL128 is only ~5% slower than Simple on NVLink at large messages while providing much lower per-hop latency.
Ring achieves optimal bandwidth for large messages. Simple protocol has ~95% link utilization with amortized ~6us sync overhead. Best combination for messages >100MB where bandwidth dominates.
Ring achieves optimal bandwidth for large messages over IB. Simple protocol provides ~95% link utilization. Combined with GDR, maximizes inter-node throughput for large gradients.

evidence.applicability: Small/medium messages, 32+ GPU multi-node, IB inter-node
evidence.mechanism: Tree has O(log k) latency vs Ring O(k). At 32+ GPUs, Tree latency advantage is significant for small/medium messages. LL128 provides 95% bandwidth with low per-hop latency. 180x latency improvement over Ring at 24k GPUs observed on Summit.
Multiple QPs provide different source ports, improving ECMP routing entropy on multi-level IB fabrics (fat-tree). Each QP independently routes through the fabric, better utilizing available paths.

evidence.applicability: Any platform without verified 128-byte atomic write support
evidence.mechanism: LL128 requires hardware guarantee of 128-byte atomic writes. PCIe platforms may not support this. Forcing LL128 on unsupported platforms causes SILENT DATA CORRUPTION. NCCL auto-detects support; never force LL128 override.
Disabling shared memory on cross-socket PCIe forces direct PCIe P2P which traverses CPU interconnect (UPI/IF). This is poorly handled on many platforms and dramatically slower than SHM transport.

Default SOCKET_NTHREADS=1 and NSOCKS_PERTHREAD=1 severely underutilizes TCP bandwidth. Multiple threads x sockets = 16 parallel TCP streams, each independently utilizing bandwidth. Single TCP connection cannot saturate high-bandwidth Ethernet.

Tree reduces number of network hops (O(log k) vs O(k)). Simple protocol minimizes number of small TCP sends. Fine-grained LL/LL128 sync creates excessive small TCP packets with poor throughput over high-latency Ethernet.

evidence.applicability: IB clusters where GPU and NIC share PCIe switch
evidence.mechanism: GPUDirect RDMA allows NIC to read/write GPU memory directly at PHB (PCIe switch) level. Eliminates extra PCIe host memory copy. 30-50% improvement for large IB messages when GPU and NIC share PCIe switch.

evidence.applicability: Compute-heavy workloads needing good overlap, NVLink intra-node
evidence.mechanism: Reducing MAX_NCHANNELS from default (often 16) to 8 frees 8 SMs for compute. On H100 (132 SMs), this returns 6% of compute capacity. Communication may see minimal degradation if bandwidth is not fully saturated, while compute-communication overlap improves significantly.
PCIe bandwidth is lower than NVLink (32-64 GB/s vs 900 GB/s). Fewer channels (4 vs default 8-16) are sufficient to saturate PCIe links. Extra channels waste SM resources without bandwidth gain.

With small messages and 16 channels, per-channel chunk size drops below 512KB NIC FIFO buffer. NIC sends partially filled buffers, wasting PCIe and network bandwidth. Also consumes 16 SMs unnecessarily.

Larger buffers (8 MiB vs default 4 MiB) create bigger pipeline chunks for Ring. Ring's non-pipelined all-reduce benefits from fewer iterations with larger chunks. Particularly helpful for very large messages (>500MB).

evidence.applicability: NCCL 2.29+ with adaptive routing on IB
evidence.mechanism: Since NCCL 2.29, adaptive routing threshold is tied to BUFFSIZE. Setting BUFFSIZE too high (16 MiB+) can disable adaptive routing, which is important for load balancing on congested IB fabrics.

evidence.applicability: NVSwitch systems (DGX H100, DGX B200, GB200 NVL)
evidence.mechanism: NVLS offloads collective reduction to NVSwitch hardware. Reduces GPU SM usage and provides near-wire-speed reductions. Default enabled since NCCL 2.17 on NVSwitch systems. Ensures it's not accidentally disabled.

Since NCCL 2.24, CTA-based tuning preferred over NTHREADS. MAX_CTAS=8 provides enough communication CTAs while leaving most SMs for compute. NVIDIA guidance: take just enough CTAs to saturate line rate, no more.
Since NCCL 2.24, manual NCCL_NTHREADS settings may be IGNORED and can lead to incorrect behavior. The CTA-based tuning model supersedes thread-based control. Use NCCL_MIN_CTAS/MAX_CTAS instead.

evidence.applicability: 128+ GPU scale with SHARP-capable IB switches
evidence.mechanism: At 128+ GPUs, Ring O(k) latency becomes prohibitive. Tree O(log k) + CollNet SHARP offload reduces both latency and SM usage. CollNet reduces SM consumption from 16+ to 6, freeing compute resources.

LL protocol has only 25-50% bandwidth efficiency due to 50% flag overhead (4B data + 4B flag per 8B). For large messages, this wastes enormous bandwidth. LL also forces host memory (disabling GPUDirect RDMA), further degrading performance.

IB timeout = 4.096us x 2^TIMEOUT. At large scale (1000+ GPUs), fabric congestion and adaptive routing can cause legitimate delays exceeding default timeout (22). Increasing to 24 provides ~4x more headroom, preventing spurious QP disconnections.

For tiny messages (<64KB), latency completely dominates transfer time. LL has lowest per-hop latency (~1us). Tree has fewest hops (O(log k)). Together, they minimize total latency for small control messages and synchronization barriers.

Ethernet/TCP has higher overhead per channel than NVLink or IB. With limited TCP bandwidth, splitting across many channels gives each insufficient bandwidth. 2 channels is typically sufficient for Ethernet.
CROSS_NIC=2 (default) allows different rings/trees to use different NICs. On multi-NIC nodes (DGX/HGX with 8 NICs), this distributes traffic across all NICs for maximum aggregate bandwidth.

evidence.applicability: Messages 12-100MB, NVLink intra-node or IB inter-node
evidence.mechanism: For messages in 12-100MB range, Ring provides optimal bandwidth while LL128 maintains low per-hop latency (~2us). This is the transition zone where bandwidth is ramping up but latency still matters. LL128 achieves 95% bandwidth — nearly matching Simple — while providing better pipelining characteristics.
